before_start:
What you need before you start:
1. 20% nutrient Zobell plates
2. Top agar – 3.5 ml per plate
       a. 100% nutrient Zobell
       b. 6g agar/liter
3. Your host grown to exponential phase.  You will need 0.4ml for each plate in the assay.
4. Phages to be tested.  This could be
          a.  a lysate (0.2 µm filtered)
          b.  a plaque picked into buffer
          c.  an environmental sample
          d.  a sample from an experiment (e.g., a one-step growth curve assay)
5.  A water bath set to 40oC.
affiliation: Matthew Sullivan Lab, University of Arizona, The Ohio State University

components.data: First, autoclave the top agar to melt it.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: First, autoclave the top agar to melt it.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 1 of Plaque Assay Protocol for Pseudoalteromonas
source_data.annotation: Note:  If your top agar was autoclaved previously, liquify it by putting it in a microwave (no stir bar!) and heating until it is completely melted.
source_data.thread_text: Note:  If your top agar was autoclaved previously, liquify it by putting it in a microwave (no stir bar!) and heating until it is completely melted.
source_data.body: Note:  If your top agar was autoclaved previously, liquify it by putting it in a microwave (no stir bar!) and heating until it is completely melted.
source_data.affiliation: Matthew Sullivan Lab, University of Arizona, The Ohio State University

components.data:
While the autoclave is running: 
a. Let your bottom agar plates warm to room temperature and label them
b. Make whatever dilutions of your phages you plan to plate

Note:  it is wise to plate one dilution higher and one dilution lower than what you calculated as optimal
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
While the autoclave is running: 
a. Let your bottom agar plates warm to room temperature and label them
b. Make whatever dilutions of your phages you plan to plate

Note:  it is wise to plate one dilution higher and one dilution lower than what you calculated as optimal

components.data: Aliquot the agar into tubes and place in 40°C water bath.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Aliquot the agar into tubes and place in 40°C water bath.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 3 of Plaque Assay Protocol for Pseudoalteromonas
source_data.annotation: Before you use the agar, make sure the tube feels the same temperature as the water bath. If the agar is still too hot, you’ll kill your host You’ll need to wait about 5—15 minutes for it to cool down enough. If the agar is too cool, it might start getting chunky If your agar is starting to solidify, do NOT use it Make up a new tube if your big bottle is still hot or re-autoclave it If it will take you more than 30 minutes to do all your infections, you’re doing too many at a time – your agar will start to solidify
source_data.thread_text: Before you use the agar, make sure the tube feels the same temperature as the water bath. If the agar is still too hot, you’ll kill your host You’ll need to wait about 5—15 minutes for it to cool down enough. If the agar is too cool, it might start getting chunky If your agar is starting to solidify, do NOT use it Make up a new tube if your big bottle is still hot or re-autoclave it If it will take you more than 30 minutes to do all your infections, you’re doing too many at a time – your agar will start to solidify
source_data.body: Before you use the agar, make sure the tube feels the same temperature as the water bath. If the agar is still too hot, you’ll kill your host You’ll need to wait about 5—15 minutes for it to cool down enough. If the agar is too cool, it might start getting chunky If your agar is starting to solidify, do NOT use it Make up a new tube if your big bottle is still hot or re-autoclave it If it will take you more than 30 minutes to do all your infections, you’re doing too many at a time – your agar will start to solidify
source_data.affiliation: Matthew Sullivan Lab, University of Arizona, The Ohio State University

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 3 of Plaque Assay Protocol for Pseudoalteromonas
source_data.annotation: If you are preparing more than one plate with the same host, you can aliquot enough top agar for however many plates you are comfortable doing at one time (up to 12) into a sterile 50 ml conical tube.  Be sure to leave room in your tubes to add host.
source_data.thread_text: If you are preparing more than one plate with the same host, you can aliquot enough top agar for however many plates you are comfortable doing at one time (up to 12) into a sterile 50 ml conical tube.  Be sure to leave room in your tubes to add host.
source_data.body: If you are preparing more than one plate with the same host, you can aliquot enough top agar for however many plates you are comfortable doing at one time (up to 12) into a sterile 50 ml conical tube.  Be sure to leave room in your tubes to add host.
source_data.affiliation: Matthew Sullivan Lab, University of Arizona, The Ohio State University

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 3 of Plaque Assay Protocol for Pseudoalteromonas
source_data.annotation: Use 3.5 ml top agar per plate
source_data.thread_text: Use 3.5 ml top agar per plate
source_data.body: Use 3.5 ml top agar per plate
source_data.affiliation: Matthew Sullivan Lab, University of Arizona, The Ohio State University

components.data: Pipet 100 μl of your phage sample onto the plate
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Pipet 100 μl of your phage sample onto the plate

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 4 of Plaque Assay Protocol for Pseudoalteromonas
source_data.annotation: If you made up agar aliquots for more than one plate, add phage to each plate now.
source_data.thread_text: If you made up agar aliquots for more than one plate, add phage to each plate now.
source_data.body: If you made up agar aliquots for more than one plate, add phage to each plate now.
source_data.affiliation: Matthew Sullivan Lab, University of Arizona, The Ohio State University

components.data: Remove the agar tube from the water bath and add the host to it using a 1 ml or 5 ml pipettor
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove the agar tube from the water bath and add the host to it using a 1 ml or 5 ml pipettor

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 5 of Plaque Assay Protocol for Pseudoalteromonas
source_data.annotation: Pipet up and down or gently invert to mix. Try not to introduce a lot of bubbles (i.e., do not shake or vortex the tube).
source_data.thread_text: Pipet up and down or gently invert to mix. Try not to introduce a lot of bubbles (i.e., do not shake or vortex the tube).
source_data.body: Pipet up and down or gently invert to mix. Try not to introduce a lot of bubbles (i.e., do not shake or vortex the tube).
source_data.affiliation: Matthew Sullivan Lab, University of Arizona, The Ohio State University

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 5 of Plaque Assay Protocol for Pseudoalteromonas
source_data.annotation: Use 0.4 ml of host per plate.
source_data.thread_text: Use 0.4 ml of host per plate.
source_data.body: Use 0.4 ml of host per plate.
source_data.affiliation: Matthew Sullivan Lab, University of Arizona, The Ohio State University

components.data: Add 3.5 ml of the agar/host mixture to each plate.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Add 3.5 ml of the agar/host mixture to each plate.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 6 of Plaque Assay Protocol for Pseudoalteromonas
source_data.annotation: If you want your plates in stacks, stack them as you go. They cannot be moved after plating for at least an hour.
source_data.thread_text: If you want your plates in stacks, stack them as you go. They cannot be moved after plating for at least an hour.
source_data.body: If you want your plates in stacks, stack them as you go. They cannot be moved after plating for at least an hour.
source_data.affiliation: Matthew Sullivan Lab, University of Arizona, The Ohio State University

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 6 of Plaque Assay Protocol for Pseudoalteromonas
source_data.annotation: A 5 ml pipettor works well for adding the agar/host to the plates.  If only one plate is prepared, you can simply pour the contents of the tube onto the plate.
source_data.thread_text: A 5 ml pipettor works well for adding the agar/host to the plates.  If only one plate is prepared, you can simply pour the contents of the tube onto the plate.
source_data.body: A 5 ml pipettor works well for adding the agar/host to the plates.  If only one plate is prepared, you can simply pour the contents of the tube onto the plate.
source_data.affiliation: Matthew Sullivan Lab, University of Arizona, The Ohio State University

components.data: Swirl the plate to spread the agar making sure it covers the whole plate.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Swirl the plate to spread the agar making sure it covers the whole plate.

components.data: Leave the plates on the bench overnight
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Leave the plates on the bench overnight

components.data: Count or pick plaques the next day
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Count or pick plaques the next day

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 9 of Plaque Assay Protocol for Pseudoalteromonas
source_data.annotation: If you’re calculating PFU, you will probably need to leave them out and count them for one more day.
source_data.thread_text: If you’re calculating PFU, you will probably need to leave them out and count them for one more day.
source_data.body: If you’re calculating PFU, you will probably need to leave them out and count them for one more day.
